I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country programming mission in Manila in 
December 2010, the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested ADB to 
provide policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) to address challenges in the institutional 
framework and administration system on environmental protection and related human resource 
development. This TA was then included in ADB’s PRC country operations business plan, 
2011–2013. 1 In  September  2011,  an  ADB  mission  visited  the  PRC  and  reached  an 
understanding  with  the  government  on  the  TA  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  costs  estimates, 
financing plan, implementation arrangements, and consultants’ terms of reference. The TA 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. The TA builds on past and ongoing ADB 
achievements, and draws lessons learned from these interventions to support the efforts of the 
Ministry of Environmental Protection (MEP) in addressing the key issues of ongoing reform of 
the environmental administration system in the PRC.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The MEP is actively exploring innovative approaches that will transform its institutional 
arrangements and administrative system into being cost-effective and supportive of the PRC’s 
emission  reduction  targets  during  the  12th  Five-Year  Plan  (2011–2015).  The  government 
envisages that the institutional reform of the MEP will ultimately contribute to the development 
goal of livelihood improvement. In March 2008, the National People’s Congress of the PRC 
passed  the  super  ministry  reform  motion  and  elevated  the  State  Environment  Protection 
Administration (SEPA) to the MEP. The main objective of the reform motion was to reduce the 
problem  of  overlapping  government  responsibilities  by  combining  departments  with  similar 
levels of authority and closely related functions. By enlarging the responsibilities and authority 
under the super ministry reform, it was intended that the previously interdepartmental tasks 
would  become  intradepartmental  tasks,  allowing  a  single  department  to  deal  with 
comprehensive  problems  from  multiple  perspectives.  The  reform  further  strengthens  the 
administrative  stability,  political  will,  decision  making  power,  and  access  to resources  with 
regard  to  environmental  protection.  However,  the  MEP  continues  to  confront  specific 
administration  and  institutional  challenges  as  part  of this reform  process,  both  horizontally 
(overlap of jurisdiction and responsibility between the MEP and other sector agencies)3 and 
vertically (where responsibility for environmental protection falls under double leadership, i.e., 
the MEP and local governments). Weak human resource capacity to support implementation of 
the administration and management system reform process is also a major obstacle.  
 
3.  To  improve  the  enforcement  capacity  of  national,  regional,  and  local environmental 
agencies,  ADB  provided  the  government  with  TA  (i)  on  transjurisdiction  environmental 
management in 2000,4 (ii) to help develop the regional supervision centers (RSCs) of the MEP 
(then the SEPA) in 2005, and (iii) on Strengthening Enforcement of Environmental Laws and 
Regulations.5

4.  The  MEP  and  the  World  Bank  completed  a  preliminary  analysis  of  environmental 
administration in the PRC in 2009. The key recommendations from the joint analysis were that (i) 
the  roles  and  responsibilities  of  relevant  government  agencies  should  be  clarified;  (ii) 
environmental laws should be reformed and strengthened; (iii) a national environmental policy 
office should be established; (iv) the MEP’s organizational structure and operational capacity 
should be strengthened; and (v) the environmental supervision responsibilities and mandate at 
the regional level (i.e., the regional supervision centers) should be strengthened. The other main 
lesson learned from the previous TA projects (as highlighted in the draft TA completion report) 
was that timely assistance to the PRC was a critical factor which contributed to the success as 
the TA progressed concurrently with the government’s institutional development and therefore 
the two processes mutually benefited. TA workshops and seminars were well utilized to discuss 
the  mandates,  functionality,  and  staffing  of  the  RSCs  while  these  centers  were  being 
established through parallel government efforts.  
 
5.  ADB has also undertaken a broad assessment of the environment and development 
framework in the PRC, as well as the state of environment, accompanied by an analysis of the 
technical,  economic  and  institutional  causes  underlying  the  environmental  problems.6 This 
resulted in a comprehensive series of recommendations on how ADB can most effectively 
contribute to the government’s broad environmental planning objectives. From the policy and 
institutional perspective, the assessment concluded that the PRC’s recent record in terms of 
promoting the policy and institutional framework for environmentally sustainable development 
has been significant. The assessment further noted that the government has been investing 
substantial sums in the environment sector, not only through programs administered by the 
MEP but also through other agencies such as the State Forestry Administration and the Ministry 
of Water Resources. The key recommendations of this assessment include, among other things, 
that there is a need to (i) provide a better balance between centralized and decentralized 
implementation, and (ii) resolve disparities between regions, local governments, and sectors. 
 
6.  Building on the key findings and recommendations of the past initiatives, the government 
requested ADB to provide TA to help the MEP prepare (i) a detailed plan for an improved 
administration system and institutional framework for environmental protection in the PRC; and 
(ii) recommendations for strengthening the policy framework required to increase environmental 
protection  skills,  and  human  resources  development  within  the  government  departments 
responsible for environmental protection. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.   The  TA  will  contribute  to  improved  environmental  management  and  sustainable 
development  in  the  PRC  by  providing  support  for  addressing  of  the  key  challenges  in 
environmental  administration  in  the  PRC. The  impact  of the  proposed  TA  is  an  improved 
environmental  administrative  system  with  enhanced  human  resources  capacity  for 
environmental protection and management in the PRC. The expected TA outcome is increased 
institutional  capacity  of  the  MEP  for  environmental  administration  and  human  resource 
development. 
 
                                                
6   ADB. 2011. Country Environmental Analysis 2011: People’s Republic of China. Manila.

3 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  Output 1: A detailed plan for an improved administration system and institutional 
framework for environmental protection in the PRC. This output will address the challenges 
in the institutional framework and administration system on environmental protection. A detailed 
plan that addresses both vertical and horizontal challenges in the institutional arrangements and 
administration  system  on  environmental  protection  will  be  prepared.  From  the  vertical 
perspective, there is ambiguity in responsibilities and/or authorities between the MEP and local 
governments. The local environment protection departments do not have any direct reporting 
responsibilities to the MEP, but report to the local governments which may at times have 
conflicting  priorities  with  the  MEP  on  environmental  protection  issues.  From  the  horizontal 
perspective, the government’s functions  on  environmental  protection have  been  distributed 
between various departments such as environmental protection, land, minerals, forests, water, 
and fisheries. The relationship and coordination between these various framework departments 
is unclear. Reform of the environmental protection administrative system in the PRC is therefore 
an  urgent  priority.  From  the  financial  perspective,  the  plan  will  provide  specific 
recommendations  on  how  the  TA  will  build  on  the  achievements  of  the  ADB-financed 
institutional  development  of  the  SEPA’s  regional  environmental  supervision  centers  and 
investigation institutes.7 Suboutputs will include the following:  
(i)  analysis of the current situation and economic development trends in the PRC 
and the subsequent environmental problems, as well as the demand for an 
innovative environmental administration approach;  
(ii)  a needs assessment to scope the MEP’s key priorities in relation to its reform 
agenda;  
(iii)  a report on the PRC’s current institutional setup and administration system on 
environmental protection with recommendations for reform of the system; this will 
include a comprehensive analysis of the functions and responsibilities of the 
environmental  protection  departments  and  other  relevant  ministries  and/or 
departments,  including  the  overlapping  functions,  including  financing 
environmental  administration;  the  report  will  analyze  and  provide 
recommendations  on  both  the  vertical  and  horizontal  environmental 
administration issues faced in the PRC (para. 2); this assessment will include a 
case  study  on  the  lessons  learned  from  an  integrated  large  department  or 
intersector administration system that has been piloted in some cities;8 it may 
also include lessons learned from the institutional setup of the various watershed 
management committees in the PRC; 
(iv)  establishment  of  an  indicator  system  for  assessment  of  environmental 
administration in the PRC; and  
(v)  a review of international experiences in administration and institutional setup for 
environmental protection (including an international study tour).  
 
9.   Output  2:  Recommendations  for  strengthening  the  policy  framework  on 
environmental  protection  skills  and  human  resources  capacity  within  environmental 
protection departments9. Suboutputs will include the following:  
(i)  a review of existing policies on human resource development; the review will 
provide specific recommendations on establishment of a system for managing 
the human resource development process;

(ii)  a review of international experiences on training and capacity development with 
regard to personnel responsible for environmental protection;  
(iii)  preparation  of  an  evaluation  scheme  on  the  human  resources  capacity  in 
environmental  protection  in  the  PRC,  which  includes  methodologies  and 
modeling tools, analysis of policies and mechanisms relating to the cultivation of 
environmental protection skills, and the establishment of a forecasting system for 
human resources development;10 and  
(iv)  preparation  of  a  policy  framework  for  human  resources  development  in 
environmental protection and management in the PRC. 
 
10.  Output 3: A knowledge product (policy brief) summarizing the key findings and 
providing policy recommendations. The proposed theme for the publication is Environmental 
Administration and Management in the PRC–an Innovative Way Forward. The key innovations 
are expected to result in recommendations for possible solutions to deal with the vertical and 
horizontal administration issues described in para. 2. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.   It is proposed that ADB provide $450,000 equivalent on a grant basis from its Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will provide in-kind counterpart 
costs and services including the provision of necessary data, office space, local transportation, 
workshop costs, and other administrative support. The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months from 1 December 2011 to 31 May 2013. 
The MEP will be the executing agency. A high-level consultative committee will be established 
for consultation on major project issues. The consultative committee will be led by the Human 
Resources Department of the MEP, and the Department of Policies, Laws, and Regulations. 
Leaders and/or experts from other agencies, and line ministries will be invited to be members of 
this committee.11 A senior fellow of the China Engineering Academy will be appointed as the 
honorary chair of this committee. 
 
13.  A  steering  committee  will  be  established  to  provide  guidance  with  the  project 
implementation process. The director general of the Human Resources Department of the MEP 
will be the chair of the steering committee, with the deputy director general of the Human 
Resources Department and the leader of the Foreign Economic Cooperation Office (FECO) as 
vice-chairs. The steering committee will comprise officers from the relevant divisions and/or 
offices of the Human Resources Department and division I of FECO. A TA management office 
will  be  established  in  MEP–FECO  to  carry  out  TA  operations.  The  director  of  project 
management division 1 of FECO will serve as the executive director of the TA management 
office responsible for day-to-day operational matters among ADB, consultants, and related 
government agencies. The TA management office will also ensure active participation and input 
from provincial departments. In addition to the specific provincial case studies (footnote 6),

14.  It  is  estimated  that  the  TA  will  require  3  person-months  of  international  consulting 
services and 32 person-months of national consulting services. Five national consultants (an 
environmental policy and institutional specialist, an environmental human resources specialist, a 
public administration specialist, an environmental legislation specialist, and an environmental 
administration human resources specialist) and one international consultant (an environmental 
policy and/or institutional specialist) will be required for TA implementation. The consultants will 
be engaged by the MEP through a firm, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) using the quality- and cost-based selection 
method, with a cost–quality ratio of 80:20. The simplified technical proposal approach will be 
used. Equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as 
amended from time to time), and will be handed over to the MEP upon completion of the 
proposed  TA.  The  executing  agency  will  be  responsible  for  all  procurement.  Operational 
expenses for training, workshops, study tours, translation, and printing will be included in the 
consultant’s contract. The TA proceeds will be disbursed following ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference 
for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
15.  The government and ADB have agreed to partially delegate consultant recruitment and 
supervision  under  the  TA  to  the  MEP,  in  accordance  with  the  terms  stipulated  in  the 
memorandum of understanding on delegated TA signed between ADB and the PRC.12 
 
16.  A procurement capacity assessment of the executing agency was conducted in 2008. 
The key conclusions from that assessment were that the MEP has strong capacity to directly 
manage the recruitment of consulting services, supervise the consultants, and administer the 
consulting services contract(s) in accordance with ADB’s policies, guidelines, and procedures. 
The assessment recommended establishment of a TA management office in FECO with a 
dedicated  team  to  ensure  smooth  processing,  implementation,  and  administration  of  the 
proposed advisory TA. It also emphasized that close interaction with and support from ADB staff 
was critical to ensure successful delegation and timely execution of the proposed advisory TA. 
These  recommendations  have  been  adopted  and  the  MEP  has  been  involved  in  the 
implementation of several delegated TA projects; ADB has provided the necessary capacity 
development throughout the process (e.g., a senior procurement officer provided support during 
the contract negotiations). 
 
17.   The  MEP  requested  the  use  of  advance  contracting  for  the  engagement  of  TA 
consultants. The mission advised the MEP that advance contracting is a normal procedure and 
that ADB’s approval of advance contracting does not necessarily commit ADB to approve the 
TA or to finance the engagement costs.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  the  Innovations  in  Administrative 
Functions of Environmental Protection and Human Resources Development, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  A consulting firm will be engaged for this technical assistance (TA). It is estimated that 
the TA will require 3 person-months of international consulting services and 32 person-months 
of national consulting services. The final input of consultants will be decided based on simplified 
technical proposals to be submitted by the shortlisted firms. The consulting firm will be engaged 
by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
A.  Environmental Policy and Institutional Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
 
2.  An  international  environmental  policy  and  institutional  specialist  with  knowledge  of 
environmental  administration  and  institutional  arrangements  will  support  the  national  team 
leader. The environmental policy and institutional specialists will have (i) at least 10 years of 
international  experience  in  environmental  administration  and  institutional  issues  in  both 
developed countries and emerging economies; (ii) experience  in and understanding of the 
environmental institutional setup and challenges in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), with 
working experience in the PRC; and (iii) demonstrated experience in the preparation of similar 
assessments. The specialist will 
(i)  work together with the team leader and refine the overall study framework and 
outlines of the inception, interim, and final TA reports; 
(ii)  conduct a review of international experiences in administration and institutional 
setups for environmental protection for both developing countries and emerging 
economies;  
(iii)  assist in developing a program and identifying institutions for the international 
study tour; 
(iv)  support the team leader in preparing the assessment report on the PRC’s current 
institutional setup and administration system on environmental protection;  
(v)  provide  input  into  preparing  the  strategic  plan  and/or  road  map  for 
operationalizing  the  reform  of  the  environmental  administration  system  and 
institutional setup in the PRC; 
(vi)  contribute to drafting and reviewing the inception, interim, and final TA reports; 
(vii)  participate  in  project  workshops  (inception,  midterm,  and  final)  and  other 
seminars presenting the TA results;  
(viii)  take  the  lead  in  preparing  the  knowledge  product  entitled  Environmental 
Administration and Management in the PRC–an Innovative Way Forward, to 
synthesize the key lessons learned and/or outputs of the TA, based on the 
outcome  of  the  study  and  in  consultation  with  the  executing  agency,  TA 
consultants, and ADB; and 
(ix)  provide input into other related technical tasks as requested by the team leader. 
  
B.  Team Leader and Environmental Policy and Institutional Specialist (national, 10 
person-months) 
 
3.  The  team  leader  and/or  environmental  policy  and  institutional  specialist  will  be 
responsible for the overall coordination and supervision of the TA activities and outputs and 
day-to-day  liaison  with  the  Ministry  of  Environmental  Protection  (MEP)  and  other  national 
government agencies supporting the related work. The team leader and/or environmental policy 
and  institutional  specialist  should  have  (i)  at  least  10  years  of  experience  with  the  PRC 
environmental administration and management system, division of government administration 
functions, and the development of environmental human resources system in the PRC; (ii)

12  Appendix 3 
 
(v)  prepare related chapters or sections of TA documents and reports; 
(vi)  participate and present relevant sections in the national workshops; and 
(vii)  conduct other related work assigned by the team leader.  
 
D.  Public Administration Specialist (national, 7 person-months) 
 
5.  The public administration specialist should have (i) at least 8 years of experience in 
public  administration  related  to  environmental  administration  in  the  PRC,  and  (ii)  English 
language proficiency and demonstrated experience in compiling technical reports and other 
outputs similar to what is expected in this TA. The public administration specialist will 
(i)  review  both  international  and  domestic  environmental  administration  system 
reform;  
(ii)  evaluate the PRC’s current environmental administration system and provide 
recommendations; 
(iii)  provide  specific  recommendations  on  the  overall  idea,  strategy,  program  for 
optimizing functions and responsibilities, and coordinating mechanism for super 
ministry reform  in environmental management, based on both domestic and 
international experience; 
(iv)  participate and present relevant topics in project seminars and workshops; 
(v)  provide input to TA inception, midterm, and final reports, and revision of chapters 
and/or sections; and  
(vi)  conduct  other  related  work  assigned  by  the  team  leader,  in  particular  the 
preparation of the road map related to an environmental administration system. 
 
E.  Environmental Legislation Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
 
6.  The environmental legislation specialist should have (i) at least 10 years of experience in 
issues related to environmental legislation in the PRC, and (ii) demonstrated experience in 
writing technical papers and/or publications related to environmental legislation issues in the 
PRC. The environmental legislation specialist will 
(i)  review existing legislation related to the establishment, functioning, and mandate 
of the MEP and other relevant ministries in relation to overlapping functions and 
responsibilities; 
(ii)  conduct a detailed analysis of the administrative laws, and highlight ambiguous 
or conflicting legislation that requires additional clarification; 
(iii)  prepare  detailed  recommendations  on  legislative  reform  that  is  required  to 
address current horizontal and vertical challenges in the PRC’s environmental 
administration; 
(iv)  review  and  provide  recommendations  on  the  existing  institutional  setup  for 
environmental law enforcement, with particular emphasis on the various levels 
and functioning of regional bodies responsible for environmental law enforcement; 
(v)  participate and present relevant topics in project seminars and workshops;  
(vi)  provide input to TA inception, midterm, and final reports, and revision of chapters 
and/or sections; and 
(vii)  conduct other related work assigned by the team leader. 
 
F.  Environmental Administration Human Resources Development Specialist (national, 
4 person-months) 
 
7.  The environmental administration human resources development specialist will have (i) 
at least 5 years of professional experience related to training and capacity development for

Appendix 3  13 
environmental administration human resources development, (ii) demonstrated experience in 
writing technical papers and/or publications related to environmental legislation issues in the 
PRC, and (iii) English language proficiency and demonstrated experience in compiling technical 
reports  and  other  outputs  similar  to  what  is  expected  in  this  TA.  The  environmental 
administration human resources development specialist will 
(i)  assist the deputy team leader in assessing environmental administration human 
resources,  additional  human  resource  requirements,  and  also  methods  for 
conducting the assessments; 
(ii)  review assessment and recommendations prepared by the human resources 
development specialist; 
(iii)  prepare a policy framework for human resources development in environmental 
protection and management in the PRC; 
(iv)  prepare related chapters or sections of TA documents and reports; 
(v)  participate and present relevant sections in the national workshops; and 
(vi)  conduct other related work assigned by the team leader.  
 
8.  The consultant will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report within 1 month 
after mobilization, (ii) an interim report 12 months after the TA starts, (iii) a draft final report 16 
months after the TA starts, (iv) a final report at the conclusion of the TA, and (v) a knowledge 
product entitled Environmental Administration and Management in the PRC–an Innovative Way 
Forward. The technical reports outlined in this TA will be submitted together with the interim and 
final reports. The final report will reflect comments made by government agencies, ADB, and 
other parties. The consultants will submit all reports in English and Chinese—six copies each in 
English and Chinese to the government, and three copies in English to ADB, including one 
electronic copy on CD-ROM. The reports will be published in Chinese and English and made 
available online.
